title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON — On a night where legends are forged, Gary Payton authored a masterpiece. The Seattle SuperSonics didn’t just defeat the Boston Celtics; they were the willing spectators to a one-man tour de force, as Payton’s historic 42-point eruption powered a commanding 118-91 road victory in 1997.

From the opening tip, "The Glove" was an offensive force of nature, shedding his defensive reputation for a scoring clinic that left the Boston Garden crowd in a state of disbelieving silence. He was unstoppable, slicing through the lane and firing from the perimeter with a cold-blooded efficiency. Every Celtics defender tasked with slowing him down was left in his wake, a mere prop in his personal highlight reel.

While Vin Baker provided a strong 21-point, 11-rebound foundation, this night belonged unequivocally to Payton. His 42 points were not just a number; they were a statement, a relentless onslaught that systematically dismantled the Celtics' spirit. The game was a contest for barely a half before Payton’s singular brilliance turned it into a laugher.

Boston, led by 22 points from Rick Fox and 18 from Dino Radja, simply had no answer. They were not just beaten by a team; they were overwhelmed by an individual performance for the ages. As the final buzzer sounded on the 27-point rout, the story was written not in the final score, but in the box score next to one name: Gary Payton, who on this night, was simply untouchable.
